title: Language Development and Communication (LDC)
subject: Foundations for Early Learning and Development (2013-)

document.title: North Carolina Foundations for Early Learning and Development

659E979628BE4F239460BD01A076975C.description:
Use some conventional
letters in their writing.

509A836FF7F74047BB6B0B9ECD727ACD.description:
Imitate adult writing
conventions that they have
observed (write groups of
letter-like forms separated
by spaces, try to write on
a line, press Enter key on
computer after typing a
series of “words”).

14344D80B0E24CC48DDE50BF2A484352.description:
Use a variety of writing
tools and materials with
increasing precision.

A8254C6171B44E69BA64CF83C122A1B8.description:
Play with writing letters
and make letter-like forms.

A431B85CD0D941E5920A8BC87132EEB6.description:
Make marks they call
“writing” that look different
from drawings (vertical
series of marks for a
“grocery list,” horizontal
line of marks for a “story”).

EA5417A34D61482C8FACF8F09E6E95BB.description:
Use a variety of writing
tools and materials with
purpose and control
(pencils, chalk, markers,
crayons, paintbrushes,
finger paint, computers).

0F1511355E6C4A57B648BD0E060E1B96.description: Children use writing skills and conventions.

62B4275F177F46658283D99B9D2BA824.description:
Try to connect the sounds
in a spoken word with
letters in the written word
(write “M” and say, “This is
Mommy.”).

D513463E5B8E4E20B2535CD92665B0E9.description:
Use known letters and
approximations of letters
to write their own name
and some familiar words.

3D894065D5E94B2D8BC083812CF96AE7.description:
Show they know that
written words are made up
of particular letters (point
to the first letter of their
own name, find the first
letter of their own name in
a list of letters).

E39F4C1F0A8749AAB759C9424F157E2E.description:
Begin to use letters and
approximations of letters
to write their name.

39E946FD69364297A875A750689142D3.description: Children use knowledge of letters in their attempts to write.

3C9D3EFD4E104BA9B18E3365AF5F9CD2.description:
Independently engage
in writing behaviors for
various purposes (e.g.,
write symbols or letters for
names, use materials at
writing center, write lists with
symbols/letters in pretend
play, write messages that
include letters or symbols).

9D10C4AF809E4736ABFB4B5350CA225C.description:
Communicate their thoughts
for an adult to write.

2CF92F17683D424D9B4BA40F5461EFD5.description:
Represent thoughts and
ideas in drawings and by
writing letters or letter-like
forms.

5A732B0A452B4A33A84663541680FDBB.description:
Engage in writing behaviors
that imitate real-life situations
(e.g., make marks to take
food order during pretend
restaurant play).

61D57A6E2B0A4D098FEE1E5C5E6BF4AC.description:
With prompting and support,
communicate their thoughts
for an adult to write.

94973AC091A74180AE676840CE0CE606.description:
Represent thoughts and ideas
through marks, scribbles,
drawings, and paintings (draw
a picture of something they
did during the day, indicate
what they want for lunch with a
mark under the picture of the
food they want).

F2FD1243293048248BD7DEA9797D49C5.description:
Children use writing and other symbols to record information and
communicate for a variety of purposes.

7970812CBA0D4688B62C7B3E7D424EEF.description:
Associate sounds with the
letters at the beginning of some
words, such as awareness that
two words begin with the same
letter and the same sound.

D3CA2CD1041A455BBBC59ECC97A2201B.description:
Make some sound-to-letter
matches, using letter name
knowledge (notice the letter
B with picture of ball and say,
“Ball”; say, “ A-a-apple.”).

1903E10227B24B239B6809FCE67A04E2.description:
Recognize and name several
letters of the alphabet,
especially those in their own
name and in the names of
others who are important to
them.

46F953B1E6D44A4EB746BC9D49054D72.description:
Show they know that letters
function to represent sounds in
spoken words.

97C7ED40B36F48329FA013850AA88C4B.description:
Demonstrate an interest
in learning the alphabet.

6C9FBBE134964369AE0D891A5AD8B10A.description:
Recognize and name
some letters of the
alphabet, especially those
in their own name.

9FA4A0F85F3843CD8F2C2B3E1DC90FB0.description:
Recognize letters of the
alphabet as a special
category of print, different
from pictures, shapes,
and numerals.

43F4EEE760C74231ACEEFA5F209074CC.description:
Demonstrate an interest
in learning the
alphabet.

7CFF4F3FDC1645959053D90785DD5BDC.description:
Children begin to develop knowledge of the alphabet
and the alphabetic principle.

D29F756374104597A8ADC7475246589A.description:
Associate sounds with specific
words, such as awareness that
different words begin with the same sound

94ACF1E2E7BD4E0E95AC81BF8B0420F6.description:
Play with the sounds of
language, identify a variety of
rhymes, create some rhymes,
and recognize the first sounds in
some words.

214B9FCE36C842899A06210281B38ADB.description:
Repeat a variety of rhythmic
patterns in poems and songs
using words, clapping,
marching, and/or instruments
to repeat the rhythm or beat
syllables.

C1A4FBF8B78647C3BC604BE02656CD96.description:
Enjoy rhymes and wordplay,
and sometimes add their own
variations.

7D6F8835FE0E4BAC9748189D30EC8F87.description:
Play with the sounds of
language and begin to
identify rhymes (make
up silly-sounding words,
repeat rhyming words).

123CD0CCD0F848D5961025F449A248DD.description:
Repeat rhythmic patterns
in poems and songs
using words, clapping,
marching, and/or using
instruments.

ACA6627F26FB4E6E8383D7838153064C.description:
Participate in experiences
with songs, poems, and
books that have rhyme
and wordplay, and learn
words well enough to
complete refrains and
fill in missing words and
sounds.

4BE86913BA194CECBB85545B94B2CD60.description:
Identify their name and the names of
some friends when they see them in
print.

4CE59CE09C684CF79E8D899C7C08E885.description:
Demonstrate understanding of some
basic print conventions (the concept of
what a letter is, the concept of words,
directionality of print).

641F1000D006434888D670B80B5508E3.description:
With prompting and support, run their
finger under or over print as they pretend
to read text.

F86A20B2396B47D7BA8143745FD5FD4C.description:
Recognize print in different forms for
a variety of functions (writing message
to friend, pointing to print and saying,
“Those words tell the story.”).

0600F64F85D0461FBF19D1BE320CB897.description:
Hold a book upright while turning pages
one by one from front to back.

4028D7B4E10C46E4A5B01C0CA8816B41.description:
Demonstrate an
understanding that
print can tell people
what to do (such as
print and symbols to
organize classroom
activities—where to
store things, when they
will have a turn).

4BB50AD54D744B9687451235050EE7A9.description:
With prompting and
support, recognize
print occurs in different
forms and is used for
a variety of functions
(sign naming block
structure, “message”
on card for family
member).

50CD6EA022FB428A941C44ABCD92387A.description:
Hold a book upright
while turning pages
one by one front to
back, but not always in
order.

3DD0B8B73D014C21A906B67ECD4F4D19.description: Children develop book knowledge and print awareness.

585659A25D7F4D8BA04685D7F49B3DC1.description:
Discuss storybooks by
responding to questions
about what is happening and
predicting what will happen
next.

78612F225BF2439B85007493E4EED0AD.description:
Ask more focused and detailed
questions about a story or the
information in a book.

FA353979167349AC8D3A6731994A2CD0.description:
Relate personal experiences to
an increasing variety of events
described in familiar and new
books.

48CB334ECA624C5CA64D1AB7682E1E5D.description:
Use knowledge of the world
to make sense of more
challenging texts.

DAE33866815F4173909D8111C0A5913E.description:
Use informational texts and
other media to learn about
the world, and infer from
illustrations, ask questions
and talk about the information.

1973E05779A044FE8EC963D3BE1F21B3.description:
Imitate the special language in
storybooks and story dialogue
with accuracy and detail.

D2F61E5FD44D4F3DBC14D5A9F4DB50B5.description:
With prompting and support,
discuss storybooks by responding
to questions about what is
happening and predicting what will
happen next.

B3228A1D99574687BC77E3883C23FB62.description:
Ask questions about a story or the
information in a book.

657A831F293C46C293A5B7122616945C.description:
Relate personal experiences to
events described in familiar books,
with prompting and support.

557E3278B3CC436FB09A4816392C89D9.description:
Use their knowledge of the world
(what things are, how things work)
to make sense of stories and
information texts.

13065EC006CE40D6801C6022C0AA322D.description:
With prompting and support,
use books and other media that
communicate information to learn
about the world by looking at
pictures, asking questions, and
talking about the information.

E73FEE0C92424414910AB29F61CEF51A.description:
Imitate the special language in
storybooks and story dialogue
with some accuracy and detail.

51C3C4F42D71493FB1603BFBB94F8888.description:
Children comprehend and use information
presented in books and other print media.

17B79019717149DCBE3D5ABDEE799E5C.description:
Listen to and discuss
increasingly complex
storybooks, information
books, and poetry.

707ACA8A71114D33B089897C072A8A42.description:
Use and share books
and print in their play.

9B21D1E716604B77AB1E21C5A83DE03F.description:
Engage in reading
behaviors independently
with increased focus for
longer periods of time.

F709D830861C4A14957AA50A2E6183D8.description:
Listen to and discuss
storybooks, simple
information books, and
poetry.

A2026EA06215457D8B3A940BC76875B8.description:
Show an interest in books,
other print, and readingrelated activities.

C420A3641BB248058EC1ED071209A286.description:
Engage in reading
behaviors independently
(choose books, turn
pages but not always in
order, tell the story).

D8E2FE56177A4E89BB1D2E0547A11900.description: Children develop interest in books and motivation to read.

7DA6317B5D1144188449C26D4C15D44F.description:
Infer the meaning of
different kinds of new
words from the context
in which they are used
(for example, hear
“sandals” and “boots”
used to describe two
pairs of shoes, and
infer that the unfamiliar
shoes must be sandals
because they know that
the other pair of shoes
are boots).

2F9D0BAEBD3D4E8894E527CEC76FF316.description:
Use a growing
vocabulary that includes
many different kinds of
words to express ideas
clearly.

B17D6F86F0154D2AB9921A728F03B612.description:
Repeat familiar songs,
chants, or rhymes.

D05325188D5D4897BFD82B7116A49602.description:
Use many kinds of cues in
the environment to figure out
what words mean.

73BC96670A0F4633ADE95C7E2DD47CE9.description:
Use more than one word
for the same object and use
words for parts of objects
(e.g., dog, beagle, Rover;
arm, leg).

DD7A66D9E70546A8958C7570FDD9E477.description:
Repeat familiar songs,
chants, or rhymes.

C1EF3D760F8148C3ADA19D1E556A6A35.description: Children respond to and use a growing vocabulary.

ABEB7F74BE7548178701D98207348DC9.description:
Speak in full sentences
that are grammatically
correct most of the time.

9113DD7AB9C8499CBC71D032AB415BC3.description:
Make grammatical errors
that follow language rules
(say, “mouses” instead of
“mice”).

612ED4ADA0DA43E6B824542E7BCA53D5.description:
Communicate in longer
sentences and use
more conventional
grammar in their home
language (plurals, tenses,
prepositions).

C0BB364DF6C34100A059F9D49017F0FF.description: Children use most grammatical constructions of their home language well.

FAD3653DD89B4C548C8522708F5D0354.description:
Describe experiences and
create and/or retell longer narratives.

65A89F69F9384CD6A62C0EEC392B93AD.description:
Describe experiences
and create or retell short
narratives.

6B989E2E0BFF46CBA8BD61C74B8F5D3B.description:
Talk to themselves and
others about what they
are “working on,” what
they are doing, routines,
and events of the day.

B30777EB741C4F7CA967397D18D922C5.description: Children describe familiar people, places, things, and events.

E6A494E70E4A4CA0B65E7D8EF5A011DE.description:
Speak clearly enough to
be understood by most
people.

ED03C589E52A43DEBB71C3620891088D.description:
Adapt their communication
to meet social expectations
(speak quietly in library,
speak politely to older
relative).

85FA2489E35D4DC2937AA2D0D078C238.description:
Use language and
nonverbal cues to
communicate thoughts,
beliefs, feelings, and
intentions.

E51E2FBAE108481F9B6E375A33A3E017.description:
Speak clearly enough to
be understood by familiar
adults and children.

14D024B747194910AE94D8B57A135B66.description:
Communicate messages
with expression, tone, and
inflection appropriate to
the situation.

B7B9BBD695D04D28A894ACB0194E8C35.description: Children speak audibly and express thoughts, feelings, and ideas clearly.

E2C70687ECC743CFABB294EA376267DE.description:
Ask specific questions
to learn more about their
world, understand tasks,
and solve problems.

B4D3C1B6312D4D2699642D3F02A42548.description:
Answer more complex
questions with more
explanation (“I didn’t like
camping out because it
rained.” “Emily is my friend
because she’s nice to
me.”).

E0DA7E6D00B54BE48FFD67EDE331ACEE.description:
Use sentences or
questions to ask for things
(people, actions, objects,
pets) or gain information.

A487088D9A0148A4B0134A1253FC183D.description:
Answer longer questions
using more detail.

CCC2B195307F4F458975C97B6EB6B644.description:
Children ask and answer questions in order to seek help, get information,
or clarify something that is not understood.

39004B9E5B314D738D4388ECB3F3A3F2.description:
Participate in a group discussion,
making comments and asking
questions related to the topic.

67F7CE731BB54D378D72DC19C61EF5C5.description:
Initiate and participate in
conversations related to interests
of their own or the persons they
are communicating with.

E22B0C262F15430A8A253B1B0B5FD465.description:
Initiate and carry on conversations
that involve multiple back and
forth communications or turns
between the persons involved in
the conversation.

C943B398EDCD45EDABDC1EB89862171E.description:
Express an understanding that
people communicate in many
ways (gestures, facial expressions,
multiple spoken languages, sign
language, and augmentative
communication).

09AAA77B9BBC4A0FA49319F8DDEB3551.description:
With prompting and
support, make comments
and ask questions related
to the topic of discussion.

D373A6CB380B4E53AA1B91A61CD38219.description:
Initiate and carry on
conversations, and ask
questions about things
that interest them.

1BEC9CA7630C48599DF3816AEA5B7C78.description:
Demonstrate an
understanding that people
communicate in many
ways (gestures, facial
expressions, multiple
spoken languages, sign
language, augmentative
communication).

3B6F924045984F4C9B2338010397790A.description:
Children participate in conversations with peers and adults
in one-on-one, small, and larger group interactions.

9BA097ECC25E479E8BCD31C02B76E26C.description:
Respond to requests
for information or
action.

82A66D439CD44F7A8B2AA4457ED886B5.description:
Show understanding
of increasingly
complex sentences.

79D0BB731B9B473C8ACE0FF6B81F5A2F.description:
Follow simple multistep
directions with visual
cues if needed.

C978C48992E9424BB223A9FAEF4764A3.description:
With prompting and
support, respond to
requests for information
or action.

EB4336C04BC84EA4B0F9CEE49C5ECE97.description:
Show understanding
of increasingly
complex sentences.
